content: The quality of instruction is crucial for student learning, and federal policies emphasize the importance of good pre-service preparation for teachers. Title II, Part A of the Higher Education Act of 1965 provides financial support and accountability measures to improve teacher preparation programs. The Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA) Title II-A provides financial support and accountability measures to improve teacher preparation programs. It includes a competitive grant program for reforms in teacher preparation programs and reporting requirements for states to track program quality. The 115th Congress is considering a reauthorization of the HEA through bill H.R. 4508. The 115th Congress is considering a reauthorization of the Higher Education Act (HEA) through bills such as H.R. 4508 and H.R. 6543, which would amend and extend Title II. The authorization of appropriations for Title II-A expired in FY2011 and was extended for an additional fiscal year. The authorization of appropriations for Title II-A expired in FY2011 and was extended for an additional fiscal year under the General Education Provisions Act. Title II-A authorities have continued to be funded under various appropriations legislation, most recently under P.L. 115-245 for FY2019. Congressional action to reauthorize the HEA may continue going forward. The report provides a description of current programs and provisions in Title II-A of the Department of Education appropriations. It identifies key issues for the debate on reauthorizing the Higher Education Act, focusing on teacher preparation at institutions of higher education. The federal support for pre-service teacher preparation in the United States has traditionally focused on programs at institutions of higher education. However, the rise of alternative approaches to teacher preparation has posed challenges to existing federal policies, especially regarding program quality accountability. Most U.S. teachers have historically been trained at higher education institutions, with formal teacher training dating back to the early 20th century. Since the early 20th century, most U.S. teachers have been trained at institutions of higher education, initially at normal schools and later at schools and colleges of education within universities. Title II-A of the HEA authorizes the Teacher Quality Partnership (TQP) program, which aims to improve the quality of prospective and new teachers through enhanced preparation and professional development activities.
